subsection.title: What is an Algebraic Fraction?
subsection.p: Variables may occur in the numerator or the denominator of a fraction, or both.

statement.p:
Choose variables and write a fraction for each situation.
The five people in Tom's study group order Chinese food and agree to split the bill equally. How much will Tom's share be?
Nurit has $800 to carpet a square bedroom in her house. What price per square foot can she afford?
How long does it take an ocean liner to make a trans-Atlantic voyage?

ol.label: a
ol.li: The amount of the bill is unknown. We let b represent the total bill. Then Tom's share is \dfrac{b}{5}.
The dimensions of the room are unknown. We let L represent the length of bedroom. Then the price per square foot is \dfrac{800}{L^2}.
The distance and the speed of the liner are unknown. We let D represent the distance traveled, and R the speed, or rate. Then the time for voyage is \dfrac{D}{R}.

assemblage.p: An algebraic fraction (or rational expression, as they are sometimes called) is a fraction in which both numerator and denominator are polynomials.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: We can evaluate algebraic fractions just as we do any other algebraic expression. But we cannot evaluate a fraction at any values of the variable that make the denominator equal to zero.

ol.label: a
ol.li: For what value of a is the fraction undefined?

ol.label: a
ol.li: Because we cannot divide by zero, a fraction is undefined if its denominator is zero. This fraction is undefined for a=\alert{2}, because ~\dfrac{\alert{2}^2+1}{\alert{2}-2}=\dfrac{5}{0}.

statement.p: What is an algebraic fraction? Give an example.

answer.p: A fraction in which both numerator and denominator are polynomials.

statement.p: What values of the variable must we exclude when working with algebraic fractions?

answer.p: Any values that make the denominator equal to zero.

subsection.title: Reducing Fractions

assemblage.title: Fundamental Principle of Fractions
assemblage.p: We can multiply or divide the numerator and denominator of a fraction by the same nonzero factor, and the new fraction will be equivalent to the old one. \blert{\dfrac{a \cdot c}{b \cdot c} = \dfrac{a}{b}~~~\text{if}~~~b,~c \not= 0}

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: When we apply the fundamental principle, we often say that we are canceling common factors. In this context, "canceling" means dividing: Because division is the opposite operation for multiplication, we can cancel expressions that are multiplied together.

solution.p: We cannot cancel the 4's, because 4 is added to 8x, not multiplied. Instead, we write the numerator as a product instead of a sum. To do that, we factor the numerator. \dfrac{8x+4}{4} = \dfrac{4(2x+1)}{4} We see that 4 is a factor of the numerator, so we can divide top and bottom of the fraction by 4 to get \dfrac{\cancel{4}(2x+1)}{\cancel{4}} = \dfrac{1(2x+1)}{1} = 2x+1

statement.p: What does "canceling" mean when we reduce a fraction?

assemblage.title: Look Ahead
assemblage.p: Now we can apply our method to algebraic fractions. We must be very careful to cancel only common factors, never common terms. For this reason, we will think of reducing fractions in two steps: first factor the numerator and denominator completely, then divide by any common factors.

ol.li: Divide numerator and denominator by any common factors.

li.p: If we substitute x=\alert{4} into the original fraction and simplify, we find \dfrac{3(\alert{4})^2+12(\alert{4})}{6(\alert{4})+24} = \dfrac{48+48}{24+24} = \dfrac{96}{48} = 2 However, the reduced fraction, \dfrac{x}{2}, is equivalent to the original one, so we should get the same answer if we substitute x=\alert{4} into the reduced fraction: \dfrac{x}{2} = \dfrac{\alert{4}}{2} = 2

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: Suppose we'd like to evaluate the fraction in for x=478. Instead of substituting 478 into the original fraction, it is much simpler to use the reduced fraction, and get \dfrac{x}{2}=\dfrac{\alert{478}}{2} = 239 This the whole point of reducing a fraction: to get a simpler but equivalent expression.

statement.p: Why is it a good idea to reduce an algebraic fraction when possible?

answer.p: To get a simpler but equivalent expression.

subsection.title: Negative of a Binomial
subsection.p: How can we deal with negative factors in a fraction? First, we consider some facts about the negative, or opposite, of an expression.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: In algebra, we prefer to write such a fraction with the negative sign in the numerator, so that the standard form for the opposite of ~\dfrac{2}{3}~ is ~\dfrac{-2}{3}.

statement.p: Does a negative sign in front of a fraction apply to the numerator, the denominator, or both?

answer.p: Either the numerator or the denominator, but not both.

subsection.p: To find the opposite, or negative, of a binomial (or any other algebraic expression) we multiply the expression by -1.

assemblage.title: Negative of a Binomial
assemblage.p: The opposite of a-b is \blert{-(a-b) = -a+b = b-a}

statement.p:
Find the opposite of each binomial.
2a-3b
-x-1

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: Recall that any number (except zero) divided by itself is 1, and any number divided by its opposite is -1. For example, \dfrac{8}{-8} = -1~~~~~~\text{and}~~~~~~\dfrac{-5}{5} = -1 The same is true for binomials and other algebraic expressions, so that \dfrac{b-a}{a-b} = \dfrac{-(a-b)}{a-b} = -1 Here is an example of how opposites can arise in algebraic fractions.
